title: 105_s1750
content: SECTION 1. ADDITIONAL CERTIFICATION REGARDING DRUG-PRODUCING AND DRUG-TRANSIT COUNTRIES. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new subparagraph requiring countries to cooperate with the United States or take steps to comply with the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to comply with the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Compliance includes making adequate progress towards meeting established plans, programs, and timetables. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to comply with the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, including specific amendments to various subsections. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include additional requirements relating to qualified certification, specifically amending subsections (b) and (f) to align with the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include additional requirements relating to qualified certification. A high-level contact group should be convened in the event of a certification under subsection (b)(1)(B), including officials from the United States and the country in question. A high-level contact group should be convened with key officials from the United States and the country in question, including the Attorney General, Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, Secretary of the Treasury, Secretary of State, Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Commissioner of Customs. The group should establish specific benchmarks for each country's plan. The high-level contact group, including key officials like the Attorney General, Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, and others, should set achievable benchmarks for each country's plan to monitor progress objectively. The high-level contact group, including key officials, should establish specific, measurable goals for each country's plan to monitor progress objectively. Each benchmark must include goals related to arrests, extradition, eradication of drug-related crops, money-laundering, and other relevant matters with fixed timelines for achievement. The high-level contact group must set specific goals for each country's plan, including arrests, extradition, eradication of drug-related crops, and money-laundering, with fixed timelines. A benchmark report must be submitted to Congress annually by September 1. The President must submit a benchmark report to Congress annually by September 1, detailing the benchmarks set for each country and their progress in meeting them. The President must report annually to Congress on benchmarks set for countries and their progress in meeting them, placing emphasis on the progress made by each country with respect to the benchmarks. In future certifications, the President will prioritize a country's progress on established benchmarks when making certifications the following year. For Mexico, a high-level contact group should be convened in 1998, with provisions from subsections (i) and (j) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 applying to its activities. In 1998, provisions from subsections (i) and (j) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 should apply to the activities and certification of Mexico.
